dlgPart.npc_text:
Master Strabos, known as “Lord” Strabos behind his back, started his career as a labourer for a small trading company. His chance came when the head merchant was assassinated in a particularly vicious takeover attempt. While others hesitated to step forward in fear of making themselves the next target, Strabos, who had nothing to lose, seized the moment and stepped into the recently vacated position. He didn’t know much about the day-to-day running of the business, but he knew how to use brute force better than any of his predecessors...
Strabos took this lesson to heart – he understood that quick, bold action was often enough to carry you to victory. And it was this attitude that gave him an edge over his rivals, pushing him all the way up to the top.

“Ah, <charname>! Come in, come in. I've heard quite a lot about you, but I’ve gotta warn you – Maadoran isn’t some sleepy little village. It’s a big city. Everything’s big here – money, games, stakes. Linos might be happy to play second fiddle to Antidas. He probably even considers himself very clever for getting rid of Carrinas, but let me assure you that that’s not how we do things around here.
“I asked Linos to give me one of his best for a reason. What I need is a fresh face. I need someone very loyal to us, yet virtually unknown. I need you to talk to certain people – powerful people – and see where their loyalties lie. If an opportunity presents itself, persuade them to show certain... flexibility.”

dlgAnsw.text: “Why do you need a fresh face?”
“What exactly will I be persuading them of?”

dlgPart.npc_text:
“Are you the one that Linos sent? Finally! Now, I've gotta warn you – Maadoran isn’t some sleepy little village. It’s a big city. Everything’s big here – money, games, stakes. Linos might be happy to play second fiddle to Antidas. He probably even considers himself very clever for getting rid of Carrinas, but let me assure you that that’s not how we do things around here.
“What I need is a fresh face. I need someone very loyal to us, yet virtually unknown. I need you to talk to certain people – powerful people – and see where their loyalties lie. If an opportunity presents itself, persuade them to show certain... flexibility.”

dlgAnsw.text: “Why do you need a fresh face?”
“What exactly will I be persuading them of?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “I can’t have any of my men seen paying social visits to people of importance. In a city where intrigue is a local sport, such visits won’t be overlooked. It must be a newcomer.”

dlgAnsw.text: “What exactly will I be persuading them of?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “Gaelius isn’t interested in sharing his power. He thinks he can rule alone. I understand the sentiment, I really do. Yet the truth is, no man can rule alone today. Since Gaelius is too stubborn to listen to the voice of reason, he must be replaced with a more suitable candidate.”
“His nephew, Serenas. Gaelius should have known better than to let that wretch live.”

“The boy’s worse than useless. No skills, no ambitions, no desires. He spends most of his time bedding whores who gave him the title Victorious. He’s an embarrassment to the family, yet he *is* family.
“Had Gaelius been a smarter man, he would have staged an accident and plugged that hole, but his sister adores the boy and hopes to see him on the throne one day. I think we can make her a very happy woman and help her realize that dream earlier than she could ever expect."

dlgAnsw.text: “Whom do you want me to talk to?”

dlgPart.npc_text:
“Any man can be killed, even a man like Gaelius. I believe you were a first-hand witness to such events in Teron. You also experienced the chaos of the aftermath.
“We don’t want chaos, we don’t want in-fighting, we don’t want to give hope to people like Antidas or all the other two-bit Lords with a claim to the city. We want everything done properly and orderly. Are we on the same page, <charname>?”

“So when Gaelius falls, another must take his place without delay. Influential nobles must immediately announce their support and accept him as the true and only heir to the throne. Imperial Guards must do the same and stand firm to prevent any attempts at throwing our city into chaos.
“Talk to Lady Lorenza Calani of House Calani. Her House held Maadoran until Gaelius’ forefathers showed up en force and took the city from them. Promise her whatever she wants – her support is crucial and she knows it.
”Next on the list is Legatus Pavola of the Imperial Guards. He has no reason to support Gaelius, but he won’t be eager to be a pawn in our games either. Talk to Lord Senna too, see where he stands. He doesn’t have as much influence as Lorenza, but his is an old name. In the right circles, it still carries a lot of weight.”
END
END - go to the villa
"Ask," says Strabos, glancing at the sandglass.

dlgAnsw.text: "What can you tell me about Maadoran?"
"What does master Linos think of your plan?"

dlgPart.npc_text: “It’s the last great city, the only city that’s left. Then again, how many great cities do we need, eh? It has everything one could ever wish for, so why would you live anywhere else?”
“Linos has enough on his plate, he doesn’t have time to worry about mine. Not that his opinion matters in this case.”
“What do you have for me, <charname>?”
“Whom did you get on board?”

dlgAnsw.text: “Legatus Pavola, Lady Lorenza Calani, and Lord Senna.”

dlgPart.npc_text:
"What do you mean, Pavola is out?" asks Strabos with irritation. "He can't be out because we need him. Didn't I make myself clear?" He sighs. "Alright. Maybe it's not your fault. Maybe Pavola is too comfortable sitting in his fort and doing nothing, but that's easy to change.
"Maseus," he asks one of his men, "what do we have on the Guards currently stationed in our fair city?"
"There are *rumors*," says the man carefully, "that some Guards are working as muscle for the Forty Thieves. Here is a list of names –"
"I don't need the details," says Strabos. "Deliver the list to Legatus Varrus without delay, along with a concerned citizen who witnessed these crimes taking place."

dlgAnsw.text: "I'll have another chat with Pavola." Leave.

dlgPart.npc_text: “All three? Not bad for a farm <boy/girl>! I’m impressed. Unfortunately, we have bigger problems now.”
“Good. Unfortunately, we have bigger problems now.”

“The fucking Boatmen. After that stunt that Neleos pulled, Darista took the local chapter straight to Gaelius. They are working for him now, propping up his regime one corpse at a time.
“Someone must have talked, so they paid me a visit while you were making the rounds. They wanted names. I gave them yours.”

dlgAnsw.text: “My name? What do I have to do with all this?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “Darista runs the local Boatmen chapter. She is something of a cunt, but what else can you expect from a woman who prefers killing to raising children? She did the mercenary work for years. Joining the Boatmen was her way of settling down.”

dlgAnsw.text: “My name? What do I have to do with all this?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “If he knew, we wouldn’t be having this conversation right now. He doesn’t know – yet, but with the Boatmen on it, it’s only a matter of time.”
“It’s their job now and apparently they are better at it than I thought. Well, you didn’t think it was going to be easy, did you?”

dlgAnsw.text: “My name? What do I have to do with all this?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “You’re working for me, aren’t you, you fucking shit? That’s what you have to do with it. Gods help Linos if I find out that he fucked me and sent me an idiot...”

dlgAnsw.text: “What stops me from selling you to the Boatmen?”

dlgPart.npc_text:
“Selling me? So, you do have some ambitions? Good. You might prove to be useful after all.
“But to answer your question, I’m the guildmaster of the most powerful guild. What’s crime for other people is merely an indiscretion for someone of my status.”

“Hamza, who else? Sorry, I keep forgetting that you’ve just arrived.
“Darista, she’s the brain. The Boatmen follow her because she knows how to use her head. Business has been good ever since she took over and that's what counts. So, she brings in contracts and ol’ Hamza makes sure that they are carried out to the clients’ satisfaction.
“You can say that Darista runs the guild and Hamza manages the manpower.”

dlgAnsw.text: “Can he be bought? Any useful vices?”

dlgPart.npc_text:
“You’re full of ideas, aren’t you, <boy/girl>? If I could buy him, why would I need you?
“Hamza is a straight edge. He’ll never go against the guild.”

dlgAnsw.text: [intelligence success]“Unless he thinks that he’s saving it.”

dlgPart.npc_text: “You really think you're that good, <charname>? If Hamza doesn't like what you have to say, it will be a very short conversation. You realize that, don't you?”

“I told the Boatmen that I’ll let them know where they can find you and that’s exactly what I will do – but only when you’re good and ready.
“I’m sure that someone with your skills would be able to run circles around the Boatmen, but if my confidence is misplaced, beg Pavola to give you some of his men. Don’t the Guards have some kind of grudge against the Boatmen?
“You can use one of our houses for this purpose. You’ll have all the privacy you need and should things turn bloody, the servants are well trained and well paid to keep their mouths shut.”

dlgAnsw.text: “So, we use the Boatmen to keep the Guards in check and the Guards to keep the Boatmen in check. Do we have any real allies?”

dlgPart.npc_text:
“Real? You mean permanent? Nothing is permanent in this world, <charname>. Things change, goals change, people change. Yesterday’s ally is today’s bitter enemy.
“Carrinas was a fanatic. Pavola is a reasonable man without any illusions of grandeur. Why shouldn’t we work with him?”

“Do you expect me to do your job for you? I’m giving you the Boatmen on a silver platter.”
Strabos gives you a critical look and sighs. “If everything fails, at least buy us some time. Send them on some wild goose chase.”
“Lord Massalus. I’ve never liked him and I’m pretty sure the feeling is mutual. Might as well kill two birds with one stone.”
“Are you ready to deal with the Boatmen?”
“I’ll make the arrangements. Wait for the Boatmen at the villa.”
“Remember, if you need muscle, talk to Pavola first.”
“You’re alive,” proclaims Strabos. “What of Hamza?”

“Linos,” breathes Strabos with rage. “He fucked me. I trusted him and he sent me a fucking idiot who ruined everything! Get out of here, while you’re still breathing! I'll get someone else to do it for me.”
He gestures and his guards drag you outside, showing you no respect whatsoever.
“You’ve done well, <charname>. Go rest. We’ll have a big day tomorrow.”

“It was flawless,” smiles Strabos, beaming with joy and enthusiasm. “Lord Gaelius died in his sleep. It’s a royal, ‘no expense spared’ treatment. He could have died convulsing on the floor, choking on his own tongue, but it would have been disrespectful to the lords of the city. Before the city could be woken up, Serenas was crowned and proclaimed to be the true heir and the next Lord of House Aurelian. Pavola avowed to keep the city safe, which sent the right message to anyone who had different ideas.”
“Have a chat with Serenas. I didn’t spend a fortune on having his uncle killed only to have someone else whisper in his ear. Explain to him how this thing works, will you?”
“Get to the point. What does he offer us?”

dlgAnsw.text: “Congratulations, you're the new magistratus. While Lorenza and Senna were fighting and putting more pressure on Serenas than he could handle, I convinced them to give the position to you.”
“Serenas? Nothing. Lord Senna is holding the strings now, but I convinced him to share his power with you, *magistratus*.”
“Serenas? Nothing. Lady Lorenza is holding the strings now, but I convinced her to share her power with you, *magistratus*.”
“Nothing. He says your support won't be forgotten, but he is a lord now and there is much demand on his time.”
“It's complicated. I need more time.” Leave.

dlgPart.npc_text:
“A magistratus? Well done! Now the city will finally prosper! We’ll show them how it’s done, won’t we? Now, I wish I could say ‘rest for a few days’, but there’ll be plenty of time to rest when you’re dead. Until then, be grateful that your services are needed.
“I want you to go to Ganezzar. I got a disturbing report from Athanasius. I don’t even know what to think. If his assessment is correct, this new development is a threat to our operations and must be dealt with promptly. If Athanasius lost his fucking mind, I need to have someone already proven in place.
“Any questions?”

dlgAnsw.text: “What can you tell me about Athanasius?”

dlgPart.npc_text:
“You mean, a puppet? No matter. I’m not a helpless lordling. They will soon find that my strings are hard to pull. Now, I wish I could say ‘rest for a few days’, but there’ll be plenty of time to rest when you’re dead. Until then, be grateful that your services are needed.
“I want you to go to Ganezzar. I got a disturbing report from Athanasius. I don’t even know what to think. If his assessment is correct, this new development is a threat to our operations and must be dealt with promptly. If Athanasius lost his fucking mind, I need to have someone already proven in place.
“Any questions?”

dlgAnsw.text: “What can you tell me about Athanasius?”

dlgPart.npc_text:
“Linos,” breathes Strabos with rage. “He fucked me. I trusted him and he sent me a fucking idiot. Nothing, he says! Get out of here, while you’re still breathing.”
He gestures and his guards drag you outside, showing you no respect whatsoever.
END - Ganezzar

“You’ve heard about Meru losing his mind, talking about gods and all this nonsense? Well, Athanasius thinks that Meru’s fantasies are becoming a bigger threat than Gaelius could ever hope to be. Apparently, he’s building a cult and Athanasius feels it must be nipped in the bud before it’s too late.”

“I think that Athanasius want to stir up some shit so as not to be left out. Linos took out Carrinas. I toppled Gaelius himself. I bet Athanasius wants to show that he’s capable of daring deeds too. Not that he would mind ruling Ganezzar given half a chance.”

dlgAnsw.text: “What can you tell me about Athanasius?”

dlgPart.npc_text:
“He is a snake, so watch him with both eyes. Linos is a simpleton compared to him. Athanasius does nothing unless it benefits him somehow, and that includes sending the report. I have no idea what he expected me to do, but my choices are to ignore it or to send someone.
“Sending someone might be exactly what he wants me to do, but doing nothing won’t do at all. So, watch him and think twice before you do something, you hear me?”

dlgAnsw.text: “If he’s such a problem, why not just kill him?”

dlgPart.npc_text:
“And who’ll do all the work?” asks Strabos derisively. “I can always rely on Athanasius to get tasks done, which is more than I can say about most people in my employ. He’s very good and that’s exactly why he can’t be trusted.
“A capable man will never stop eyeing the seat of his superior, trust me on that. The problem is you need capable men on key positions or you won’t get far yourself. Of course, it’s good to shake things up every now and then and show that nobody’s untouchable, no matter how valuable, but now is not the time to do that.”
“What are you still doing here? Didn't I tell you that we need you in Ganezzar yesterday?”

dlgAnsw.text: “Just tying some loose ends, boss.” Leave.

dlgPart.npc_text: [charisma failure]“Not now, <charname>.”
[charisma success]“Of course I’m worried. A hundred things can go wrong and some of them will, but as long as we can handle them...”

dlgAnsw.text: “I’m still surprised that it’s so easy to kill a man like Gaelius.”
“How did you become a guildmaster? You don’t seem like most merchants I’ve seen.”

dlgPart.npc_text:
“Because you are looking at it the wrong way. You see a mighty lord, surrounded by guards and loyal servants. I see a man surrounded by countless people who can be turned against him at any moment. Frankly, I don’t know how he manages to sleep.
“A lord’s court is filled with people who have certain expectations. One wants to be elevated, the other wants power, or money, or someone’s estate. You can’t please everyone, at best, you can make strong allies and weak enemies, but that’s not how it works most of the time. You elevate one man, you spurn a dozen.”

“No man is safe, especially these days. A lord, of course, has more options than most, but exercising them takes guts. Gaelius should have killed Serenas, Lorenza, and everyone else who sided against him. Of course, these are what they call 'unpopular measures', but being popular is of little comfort, once you’re dead.”

dlgAnsw.text: “How did you become a guildmaster? You don’t seem like most merchants I’ve seen.”

dlgPart.npc_text: “Why should I be denied what I’ve earned because of my so-called low-birth? All men are born the same way, last time I checked, and Gaelius’ blood is no bluer than mine.”

dlgAnsw.text: “I too believe that all men are born equal.”
“No lord would ever accept such beliefs.”

dlgPart.npc_text: “Equal? They are born anything but. Most are born to serve, one way or another. Few are born to rule, born with the strength needed to achieve greatness and the blood has nothing to do with it.”

dlgAnsw.text: “So, basically, you want to create a new kind of aristocracy?”
“No lord would ever accept such beliefs.”

dlgPart.npc_text: “Basically,” agrees Strabos. “Does this conversation have a point?”

dlgAnsw.text: “I’m still surprised that it’s so easy to kill a man like Gaelius.”
“How did you become a guildmaster? You don’t seem like most merchants I’ve seen.”

dlgPart.npc_text: “Then I’ll make them,” growls Strabos. “If they accept my money, they will have to accept and tolerate my company.”

dlgAnsw.text: “I’m still surprised that it’s so easy to kill a man like Gaelius.”
“How did you become a guildmaster? You don’t seem like most merchants I’ve seen.”

dlgPart.npc_text: “That’s because I’m not,” grins Strabos. “I got tired of watching these clowns running around like chickens with their heads cut off and decided to step in. The rest was history.”

“I used to work for a small trading guild. They were negotiating some kind of deal when something went wrong and instead of a signed contract we got the guildmaster’s head delivered to us in a box. The look on the bastard’s face... I bet he never even saw it coming.
“Anyway, our entire operation was instantly paralyzed. Everyone panicked. They all pictured their heads in that box, so they did nothing. To be honest, all I cared about at that point was my pay. So, I went to talk to them about it, told them to fucking do something and they ended up offering me the job. Like, you do something, if you’re so clever.
“I did. I paid the Boatmen a fortune – almost all the money the guild had, and called a meeting with the competition. They showed up, thinking that we were ready to sign over the business, and that’s where the Boatmen got them.”

“Then? Well, that’s the funny part. The fucker who told me to do something about it came to me, expecting me to hand him the job, since he was a learned bean counter and I was nothing but a working stiff. I had his head delivered in a box to the guild, seeing how it made such a strong effect the first time around. Nobody’s bothered me ever since.”
Strabos goes on and on, talking about the early days of his reign, which gives you a good insight into the art of aggressive negotiation.

dlgAnsw.text: “I’m still surprised that it’s so easy to kill a man like Gaelius.”

dlgPart.npc_text: “What can I do for you, Praetor?”

dlgAnsw.text: “The relationship between House Aurelian and House Daratan has been strained for a very long time. Lord Gaelius’ passing is most unfortunate, yet it gives us an opportunity to turn over a new leaf.”
“Serenas wants to clean up the Slums. Here is your chance to get rid of Levir and his thieves.”

dlgPart.npc_text: “This leaf-turning business, does it go both ways?” inquires Strabos.
“I’m tired of being looked down upon. I can buy and sell these Lords, these glorified beggars by the dozens, yet without a title I’ll always be Strabos the trader to them.”
“No, but they will be forced to address me as Lord Strabos, whether they fucking like it or not.”

dlgAnsw.text: “Surely, you can afford to buy a title or two.”

dlgPart.npc_text: “I want it done right,” says Strabos. “I want Serenas himself to grant me a title and announce it to his entire court of sandal lickers. If you can promise me that, then I, in good faith, will put in a good word for you and your House.”

dlgAnsw.text: “If you have such influence, why not ask for it yourself?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “Because that’s not how the game is played, Praetor. The moment I ask for something for myself, it will be used against me. So, instead, I’ll do something for you and you’ll do something for me.”

dlgAnsw.text: “You’d trust me to keep my end of the bargain then?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “Why wouldn’t I? I’m certain that this isn’t the last time you need a favor. You don’t strike me as a short-sighted <man/woman>, Praetor.”
“Do we have a deal?”
“I’ll talk to Lord Serenas shortly.”
“We had a deal and you fucked me,” hisses Strabos, the man who aspired to enter the high society. "Get out of here."
END - get the fuck out

“I wish it was that simple,” says the freshly minted Lord of Coins. “The thieves won’t face the Guards out in the open, waiting to be slaughtered. They will fight like rats, striking from the gutters, and then they will take the fight to other districts, to hit us where it really hurts. Nobody wants that.”

dlgAnsw.text: “I thought you’d be all over it.”

dlgPart.npc_text: "I have too much on my plate at the moment, so go bother someone else with this shit."

“I hate the fuckers, but you have to be realistic. The only way to get rid of them is to close the district and then burn it to the ground. *That* would set them back for a few years. Going in to reclaim it is a fool’s errand and the consequences will be disastrous.”

“Do you think we didn’t try? They are like weeds – always grow back. We have a good “working” relationship with Levir. He’s a reasonable man and he does a good job keeping most of this scum in the Slums, where they belong.”

dlgAnsw.text: [streetwise][persuasion]“Here is the thing. Serenas, the man who gave you your title, wants to clean up the Slums. Pavola’s gonna fold and do it, it’s just a matter of time. So, your ‘no’ changes nothing, but makes you look bad. I mean, really bad.”

dlgPart.npc_text: [failure]“Then let Pavola do it and take all the blame for what would follow.”
[success]“Serenas is just a figurehead. I wouldn’t waste too much time worrying about what he wants.”

dlgAnsw.text: [streetwise success]“I would. He had Senna killed. You’ve got him all wrong.”

[persuasion]“Serenas is a figurehead, Pavola is a figurehead. Are you sure that you are not on this list too? Aren’t you a city magistratus now? Then act like one. Prove that you still have the balls to act when necessary and deal with the lowlifes who have been stealing from you for decades once and for all!”

dlgPart.npc_text: [failure]“I don't care what you say. There is nothing in it for me, so I'll stay out of it."
“Bullshit,” says Strabos, but he doesn’t sound very convincing. “I thought Lorenza was behind it. How would you even know that?”

dlgAnsw.text: [streetwise]“I killed him myself. I delivered him a message from his Lordship earlier today. He refused and died shortly after, as per Lord Serenas’ instructions.”

dlgPart.npc_text: [success]“Alright, alright, you’ve made your point. Tell Serenas that I’m behind him a hundred percent.”
END - return to Serenas

The Commercium's mercenaries block your way and escort you to Strabos.
"Do I really have to send my men to fetch you?" asks Strabos, looking annoyed. "What did Serenas say?"

dlgAnsw.text: “Congratulations, you're the new magistratus. While Lorenza and Senna were fighting and putting more pressure on Serenas than he could handle, I convinced them to give the position to you.”
“Serenas? Nothing. Lord Senna is holding the strings now, but I convinced him to share his power with you, *magistratus*.”
“Serenas? Nothing. Lady Lorenza is holding the strings now, but I convinced her to share her power with you, *magistratus*.”
“Nothing. He says your support won't be forgotten, but he is a lord now and there is much demand on his time.”
